Depends on which mythology you're talking about, and even if you can specify that you're unlikely to get a consistent figure.
As far as I can tell, in the viking-era norse stories, there's no indication whatsoever that 'dwarfs' are smaller than anyone else. Even later stuff seems pretty ambiguous.
Greek sources talk about several different forms of dwarf, some of them supernatural, others just exotic races of human. I believe that there is at least a consensus from them that dwarfs are smaller than normal people. Pliny said that the Pygmaioi were also known as Trispithami because they were just three spans (a span is about 9") tall.
English, French, and German medieval romances were usually pretty vague about how big dwarfs were (and often unclear if they were meant to be normal people who had dwarfism, members of a race of small people who were nevertheless still human, or actually supernatural beings) but again there seems to be a general consensus that they were relatively small. I've seen references to them being three spans (almost certainly copied from Pliny), one cubit (18" or so), 'knee high' (to a human), or (probably the most common measure) one ell ('arm'; a wildly variable unit ranging from the same as a cubit to over four feet, but usually about two feet).
I don't think I've ever seen any description of a legendary dwarf which is in the height range of fantasy dwarfs (which I generally think of as 4 to 5 feet). They are either not any smaller than normal people, completely ambiguous, less than 4 feet tall, or don't really fit the general dwarf archetype (e.g. a lot of pacific-region legends have stories of 'short men' who are near human height, but they are ape-men, AKA wildmen, which share little in common with European dwarf myths).

>>86742181
I'm going to concentrate on concepts with actual mythical basis, since otherwise you can pretty much include anything.
One major theme is that giants are related to gods. The titans, gigantes, and cyclops of Greek myth were ancestors, cousins, or offspring of the gods. Germanic pagans seem to have classed their 'giants' as comparable to the gods and often related to them. Asuras are god-like. In many cases, they are said to be older than the gods and may even represent 'folk memories' of previous pantheons. Sometimes they are 'anti-gods' or enemies of the gods. Even in medieval Christian traditions, where they are obviously nowhere near the power-level of God, they are portrayed as so arrogant that they think of themselves as equal to Him.
So there's a lot of ways that can be played with. Maybe giants are outcast gods who have been cast down to earth? Or the offspring of gods and mortals (and possibly able to call on their divine parents).
Another theme is that giants are primordial beings of stone. This is a very widespread idea; I know of it being mentioned in European, Asian, and American myth. Often they turn to stone on death, or have bodies as hard as stone (often immune to stone or iron weapons, for example). Make them kind of 'elemental' rather than fleshy.
Another popular theme is that giants are a mix of man and beast, mixing with the 'wildman' archetype. This is especially common in north America, but also found elsewhere. Modern fantasy writers often like to play with this, making giants resemble archaic hominids, with lots of hair, stone-age technology, brow ridges, etc. This ties in with the idea of them being 'primal' beings from the dawn of time. I guess you could run with that and take it further, with giants being reptilian (or dinosaurian), or amphibian (I think there's something like that in Theosophy), or even weirder and more ancient (such as Lovecraft's cone-beings).
